column1: Before 1 October 2021, will Jair Bolsonaro cease to be the president of Brazil?
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Non-US Politics']

President Bolsonaro is playing by the U.S. previous President's playbook. Stay in power for as long as possible and squash any opposition that stands in his way. If feel threatened by the election, publicly question the validity of the election. I am not judging Brazilians or the system but the individual solely.
The deadline is to short. It's almost impossible.

Brazil Politics: Bolsonaro Says He Won't Doubt Voting System - Bloomberg https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-09-24/brazil-politics-bolsonaro-says-he-won-t-doubt-voting-system Fri, 24 Sep 2021 15:59:06 GMT bf0307d8d6d7807028b86c0a178b6b39
Still the president with less than 10 days to go
Late to this table but anywho. With so little time to go, I'm going all in on zero.

While his popularity and disapproval rating have reached record high recently (https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/brazils-bolsonaro-disapproval-rating-rises-all-time-high-poll-2021-07-08/) , ceasing to be the president can only happen if he was toppled, or if he dies. I do not see that happening in the next 10 days. Maybe he'll be voted out next year, though.

There does not appear to be any mechanisms by which opponents of Bolsonaro could remove him from power in the next two weeks. To some extent, it seems like the most likely way for Bolsonaro to cease to be president in the short term would be for him to stage a coup and fail.
Passage of time
Passage of time

It is known that Jair Bolsonaro, the current president of Brazil, has been questioned for his mishandling of the COVID-19 crisis in his country. In fact, during the month of August there were more than 30,000 daily infections throughout the month and today (September 7) 9,154 new cases were reported. On the other hand, his popularity fell to 24%, the lowest in his term, in addition to the fact that he is being investigated for spreading false information about the elections. However, despite all the controversy in his person, there are a large number of people who support Bolsonaro, showing his favoritism in protest marchs against the judiciary that is investigating him. Some are even calling for a military intervention against the country's Supreme Court.
Down from 1% due to passage of time (about a month since last forecast).

If Brazil ceases Bolsonaro would more chaos in the country the best way to get rid of him as president is the election next year, in which Lula is seeing as good option to comeback and take over the presidency.
Passage of time update

Bolsonaro attacks Brazil judges, warns of "institutional rupture" - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/bolsonaro-attacks-brazil-judges-warns-institutional-rupture-2021-08-14/ Sat, 14 Aug 2021 16:05:00 GMT
Unless he dies...

Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro will be investigated over unproven voter fraud claims - CNN https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/05/americas/brazil-bolsonaro-fraud-supreme-court-investigation-intl/index.html Thu, 05 Aug 2021 10:59:00 GMT
He continues to live and has no new health issues, which means one potential avenue for his removal is narrowing

His support in the Congress houses and popular opinion is fragile but there is strong resistance to removing him from office. He has sufficient clout over the Lower House's most central block as the basis for their sustain is sufficient for them to not consider impeachment as a possibility. He is being investigated in multiple fronts but the processes are slow and the one with most potential for impeachment is the CPI (Inquiry Parliament Committee) which won't end soon. Besides, Impeachment is the main way that he can be removed, while it also took over two months to succeed under Rousseff's presidency. The last impeachment being not long ago also creates resistance, as the repercussions of Bolsonaro's impeachment would undermine the image of democracy, the people's trust in their chosen candidates, and other factors.
President Bolsonaro still having support among 25/30% of the voters. There is no room to be ceased.
It is snowing in the jungle down there - anything could happen.

@Jprice94 @mkarbowsky @Pablo_Vargas We've gone a week since I last answered 25%. In that time, I don't think there have been any more attempts on Bolsonaro's life, nor has he contracted any more illnesses, and his political rivals continue to appear disorganized. He could still die or be impeached, but I think it's looking less likely that he will have to relinquish office that soon.
He'll almost certainly hold on longer than that

Brazil's Bolsonaro turns to center-right senator for political survival - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/brazils-bolsonaro-turns-center-right-senator-political-survival-2021-07-27/ Tue, 27 Jul 2021 20:58:00 GMT

There are multiple avenues that lead to Bolsonaro being out of office. Oct. 1, 2021 is soon, but he 1) has health problems; 2) has been stabbed before, could happen again) 3) is corrupt and may have done, or may do something worthy of a quick impeachment. Still, he's stubborn and is unlikely to resign without tons of pressure, and there's no clear alternative that most Brazilians would find palatable in either major party, which may be a hurdle to impeachment. Plus he has inertia going for him.
Brazil's Bolsonaro leaves hospital after treatment for blocked intestine - BBC News https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-57881111 Sun, 18 Jul 2021 18:35:26 GMT

Bolsonaro is handing out parliamentary amendments to keep the congressional majority on his side. Arthur Lira, president of parliament, remains holding impeachment orders. Here, in Brazil, it is said that there is no impeachment without the people on the street, with the situation of the pandemic, the demonstrations are still small. In addition, the congress will go into recess, a fact that will postpone the probable impeachment process.
out of the hospital as of today.

holding
Only giving one percent because of many uncertainties of this age. I am not aware of any case where a markedly populist ruler would undergo impeachment.
500,000+ deaths almost 100,000 new infections per day still no impeachment

This is before Brazil's next election. This would require impeachment or something of the sort. It is pretty unlikely. Nonetheless, the fact that people are asking means that he is fairly unpopular. He could be assassinated or something. There could be a huge amount of unrest or some such, or Ukraine-style protests. I think it is quite unlikely because the Presidential elections are not for a while and Bolsonaro won with a ton of support. I will put it at 5%.

Impeachment is possible but not likely.
2% death or incapacity. 4% impeachment. 0% resignation from scandal - populists don't seem to have any shame gene. 2% overthrown/street protests etc.
this is just not going to happen, unless he gets shot or gravely ill, they probability for which is nigh zero.
Adjusted for passing time.
He's an NRA man: they will only take away the presidency from "his cold dead hands"

A pesar de que las próximas elecciones de Brasil son en 2022, creo que de igual forma existe una probabilidad de que Jair Bolsonaro deje de ser presidente de Brasil antes del 1 de octubre. Una de las principales causas de esto, podría ser la terrible gestión con que ha manejado la pandemia, registrando hasta la fecha más de 360.000 fallecidos y más de 3.600 en la última jornada, eso sumado al bajo porcentaje de vacunación de la población. Otro de lo motivos se podría atribuir a la mala situación económica que el país esta enfrentando ya que en 2020 el PIB brasileño se redujo un 4,1% con relación al año anterior, además el desempleo ha llegado al 15%, su nivel más alto desde 2012, y el coste de la vida se eleva por la alta inflación. Todo lo anterior ha hecho que la aprobación de presidente caiga drásticamente, teniendo un 44% de desaprobación general y un 54% de desaprobación a su gestión de la pandemia.

Supreme Federal Court ("Supremo Tribunal Federal") confirmed the recent overturning of a corruption conviction against Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, former Brazilian president (2003-11), however, for procedural reasons only. Next election is on schedule for 2022, but Bolsonaro has become president in 2018 because of Lula's conviction then in the first place, since he could not be eligible in that election, even though he was leading polls.

The latest opinion polls by Datafolha, taken in mid-March, suggest that 44 percent of those polled thought the Bolsonaro government was “bad or awful”, but that 30 percent thought it was “good or excellent”.
Noting @SE Meyers comments.
Bolsonaro's (and his son's) ties to mafia-like militias, and their financial profits from all sorts of illegal activity, will come under scrutiny soon. The military will withdraw their support.
No change.

Brazil is a proud country that would resist international resentment due to the response to COVID-19. Despite the scandals, like most nations COVID-19 is at the forefront of their consciousness. I am putting this at a 13% outcome, as another scandal could be his undoing, but still unlikely. As more doses of the COVID-19 vaccine are distributed worldwide the threat will die down and he will have to focus on other major priorities within the still-developing nation.
People will realize that he failed
Doesn't matter how much damage he does, since he has replaced the legislative branch and the investigative bodies with jellyfish. Sound familiar?

Brazil on 2 October 2022 to elect the President.

Updating as the timeframe has gotten closer and the probability of outside factors decreases.
Impeachment unlikely given election of allies to speakerships in congress

Allies of President Bolsonaro now control both chambers of Brazil's legislature. (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics/bolsonaro-allies-win-control-of-brazilian-congress-idUSKBN2A12WY?il=0) This development practically ensures that there will not be an impeachment since Bolsonaro's party has successfully received the support of more moderate lawmakers.

There is always a big movement of people wanting and several impeachment requests filed, but he has created an illegal network of supporters in high places of the government, judiciary and legislative that protect him, but recently, even right wing supporters have started requesting for his removal from power. It is very unlikely that he does get removed (unfortunately) but there is at least a considerable chance that he does, though if that happens, the one to assume power will most likely be Hamilton Mourão, his vice president, which is military and will probably immediately descend this country in a very rigorous military dictatorship.
https://www.reuters.com/article/brazil-politics/covid-19-not-enough-to-impeach-bolsonaro-brazils-likely-lower-house-head-says-idUSL1N2K22WU

The elections will be in 2022. Despite all the troubles Bolsonaro is and may be going through in the next months, there's no valid reason for him to step aside or be overthrown by Ocotber 2021 or before the next elections.
Reiterating previous forecast
I think he's got the military behind him, so October is unlikely.

It seems unlikely that President Bolsonaro will be removed from office before 1 October 2021 due to a number of reasons. First, with Trump's loss in the United States, and a more moderate Biden administration in place, Bolsonaro can reach out to the United States to improve trade relations between the two countries, which will benefit Brazil and bring money and cheaper goods to the country [1]. His approval rating is also at the highest as it has been at anytime in his tenure in office, due to economic measures he has undertaken while in office and it has grown amongst the poorest members of the country [2].
"Bolsonaro allies set to win control of Brazil's Congress": https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics/bolsonaro-allies-set-to-win-control-of-brazils-congress-idUSKBN29N1V6
Adjustment for time elapsed.

Enough time before 01 October 2021 to get re-infected. There are some reports that re-infections (those few observed and described) tend to behave differently and may be much more severe than the first COVID-19 disease of individuals. As Brazil is affected heavily by the second wave, and the variant P.1 has already arrived there, I'll give Bolsonaro a good chance he'll have a second haul, and will not jump off the shovel that easily this time.

People's main concerns and votes are driven by self-interest, personal gains, and individual benefits. As long as Bolsonaro will manage to sustain Brazilian economy, and give appropriate demagogic gestures to control Brazilian people's perception about his presidency, he will manage to stay in power. Coronavirus death toll will not affect the vote sufficiently. The dead don't vote.

No obvious catalysts, but feel like with a intra election very recent precedent it is probably more 2 - 10% than the very unlikely sub 2% type probabilities. Not being a part of an existing party in Congress cannot help either so maybe for Bolsanaro it is more like 5 -10%. Not at his popularity lows so going for the mid ish point of that range.
Never gives up
It is extremely difficult to remove someone from the presidency quickly in Brazil if they want to continue to do it, so unless this changes he'll cling on.
He's made of Teflon.
His term isn't up until 2022, would appear unlikely he would be removed before it's up.

Standard probability around risks of health + major scandals, with a few % more to account for possible 2nd wave of pandemic if handled badly. Unclear what his relationship with Biden will be, or if it matters much on a short timescale. On the other hand, if post-pandemic economic bounce is large, then Bolsonara likely to benefit
Bolsonaro is reportedly fairly popular right now: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2020/12/16/brazil-coronavirus-bolsonaro-popularity/
He will not give up without a fight - unless he dies.
Bolsonaro’s popularity with the people of Brazil will keep him afloat long enough. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/17/world/as-brazils-virus-crisis-eases-jair-bolsonaros-popularity-rises.html
2% death or incapacity. 1% impeachment. 0% resignation from scandal - populists don't seem to have any shame gene. 1% overthrown/street protests etc.
The populist leaders seems to weather the challenges lately
In recent memories the populist have been able to weather the challenges to their authority.

most of the major economic forces in the country are actually thriving from his performance, and his role is playing a significant favorable part for his opposers, it will all depend on the likelihood of the "middle" parties getting rid of him without empowering Lula and all the opposition within.
Not unless he gets mortally ill or killed
Has survived everything so far - seems unlikely he is turfed out.
He admires military dictatorships and aspires to remain president for the long-term.
Presidents voluntarily resigning are rare and so are impeachments.

Mid term elections nov 2020 show, that nearly all candidates supported by Bolsonaro are losing. COVID will raise again if summer is over. His sons are under fire by the justice. Fires in the Amazon forest will gain new high scores and will raise political pressure from abroad. He by himself has the potential to make something stupid, which end his career.
Using @pietrokc's logic, but rounding up slightly for death + general risk of politics.
Incompetence, scandal, worsening COVID.
Scandals unlikely to bring him down this late in Covid's terror

I estimate that there's around a %2.5 chance that Bolsonaro dies before 1st October 2021, based on the actuarial estimate of the chance of death for a 75 year old (about %3.56 per year) multiplied by 5/6 to adjust for the 10 months remaining and further adjusted downwards to account for Bolsonaro not being representative.
a little time, regular change of president, second place of president's party
To much turmoil and therefore room for corruption.

As with Trump in the US, I think it is unlikely Bolsonaro will be removed outside of an election. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Brazilian_general_election I expect him to be re-elected in the next general election given his approval rating: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics-poll/poll-shows-jump-in-approval-for-brazils-bolsonaro-amid-pandemic-idUSKCN26F369

Because despite the horrible treatment he had of the pandemic in Brazil, he survived politically, I see it difficult for them to remove him from the presidency and despite everything he maintains an acceptable level of approval.

Ways Jair Bolsonaro would cease to be president: overthrown, step-down, assassination, die of normal causes. The question is leading, assuming that scandals will be the predominant cause of him no longer being president. Because of the international diversity of COVID response, I actually do not believe that the devastating numbers in Brazil will be the leading cause of Bolsonaro ceasing to be president. Given unforeseen events that would eliminate him as President, I think there is a likely chance, however, I see Bolsonaro maintaining his position until the next presidential election in 2022.

Perhaps if he botches the vaccinations, economy continues to suffer and they have a debt crisis - all of which could happen. Popularity is pretty low and had a dead cat bounce. He'd have to be pushed out pretty convincingly but we live in very turbulent times right now.

The rationale by @pietrokc makes a lot of sense, and it would be presumptuous of me to think I can assign a higher probability than he did. Also, Bolsonaro's polling numbers are good: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_on_the_Jair_Bolsonaro_presidency
Sworn in on the 1/1/2019, Bolsonaro would have been President of Brazil for 1004 days on the 30/9/2021.

Where once impeachment talks were gaining traction, Bolsanaro is now enjoying a level of popularity not seen since the beginning of his term in office. The COVID-19 emergency relief payments (i.e. unconditional cash transfers), which significantly improved living conditions in the most economically underprivileged areas of Brazil, have proved particularly helpful.

In Brazil impeachment needs 2/3 majority in Congress and then 2/3 majority in the Senate. The govt coalition has 47% of the seats in Congress. The Senate is 1/3 govt, 4/9 "independents", and 2/9 opposition. However the 4/9 "independents" are all of parties that impeached the previous president, and the current president defines himself most of all in opposition to the previous one.

There is reportedly a 'misconduct' investigation underway of Bolsonaro, FWIW: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/brazil-bolsonaro-corruption-sergio-moro/2020/11/20/dfd4e9f0-282e-11eb-92b7-6ef17b3fe3b4_story.html
Extremists like Bolsonaro usually cling to their office
At this point he appears to be untouchable after his 2018-2020.
Impeachment and removal from office is a bit more common in Brazil than it is in the US.
I doubt he will die, but maybe some scandal pops up.
